titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: University of Delaware Special Collections Department Morris Library, 181 South College Avenue Newark, DE 19717-5267

bioghist.p: David Lenox was the United States Marshall for the Pennsylvania District Court during the Whiskey Rebellion. Lenox also served as the President of the Bank of the United States, and was a businessman and land speculator. His wife was Tacy Lukens.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of David Lenox. Materials include: correspondence relating to Lenox's career subsequent to the Revolution (land speculation, duties in the Whiskey Rebellion, executorship of the estates of John Lukens and Joseph Prowell, and banking); personal business and household receipts; and records related to the settlement of his estate. Included in the collection is Alexander Hamilton's and Richard Peters's letter of November 11, 1794, thanking Lenox for his government service, but urging him to the bedside of his sick wife. Also included are letters from Robert and William Pulsford advising Lenox on the financial affairs of the Washington Plantation. These letters contain discussions of the sale of slaves. Other correspondents include Horace Binney, William Bradford, George Fisher, Alexander Graydon, Robert Lenox, Levi Lincoln, various members of the Lukens family, various members of the Prowell family, and Forsyth Smith & Co.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

acqinfo.p: Provenance: Gift of Anna D. Moyerman.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Pennsylvania State Archives: Lukens-Lenox papers.
